title: Data Displays: Bar Graphs and Dot Plots
description: Create and interpret bar graphs and dot plots to display and analyse data
objectives: Compare data using graphs and answer questions about the data

sections.title: Showing Data with Graphs!
sections.content:
You've already learned about tally marks and picture graphs. Now it's time to level up! **Bar graphs** and **dot plots** are more powerful ways to display data.

Graphs make it easy to see patterns, compare groups and answer questions about data at a glance.

sections.title: Bar Graphs
sections.content:
A **bar graph** uses rectangular bars to show data. The taller (or longer) the bar, the bigger the number.

Every bar graph needs:
- A **title** (what the graph is about)
- **Labels** on both axes (what each axis shows)
- A **scale** on the number axis (the numbers go up by equal amounts)

**Example: Favourite Sports**

| Sport | Number of students |
|-------|-------------------|
| Soccer | 12 |
| Cricket | 8 |
| Netball | 10 |
| Swimming | 6 |

From this bar graph we can tell:
- **Soccer** is the most popular ($12$ students)
- **Swimming** is the least popular ($6$ students)
- $12 + 8 + 10 + 6 = 36$ students were surveyed
- Soccer has $12 - 8 = 4$ more votes than cricket

sections.title: Dot Plots
sections.content:
A **dot plot** (or line plot) uses dots stacked above a number line. Each dot represents one piece of data.

**Example: Number of Pets Owned**

Imagine dots stacked above the numbers 0, 1, 2, 3, 4:
- Above 0: 3 dots (3 students have 0 pets)
- Above 1: 7 dots (7 students have 1 pet)
- Above 2: 5 dots (5 students have 2 pets)
- Above 3: 2 dots (2 students have 3 pets)
- Above 4: 1 dot (1 student has 4 pets)

**Reading a dot plot:**
- The **tallest stack** shows the most common value (called the **mode**)
- Here the mode is **1 pet** (7 students)
- Total students: $3 + 7 + 5 + 2 + 1 = 18$

Dot plots are great for showing how data is **spread out**.

sections.title: Example: Reading a Bar Graph
sections.content:
A bar graph shows how students get to school:
- Walk: 15
- Car: 10
- Bus: 8
- Bike: 5

How many more students walk than ride the bus?
steps: Find the value for Walk: 15 students
Find the value for Bus: 8 students
**7 more students** walk than ride the bus

sections.title: Choosing Between Graphs
sections.content:
Different types of graphs work best for different situations:

| Graph type | Best for |
|-----------|----------|
| **Picture graph** | Young audiences, small data sets |
| **Bar graph** | Comparing categories (favourite colours, sports) |
| **Dot plot** | Showing the spread of numerical data (test scores, heights) |

**Tips for creating a good graph:**
- Always include a **title**
- **Label** your axes
- Use a **consistent scale** (go up by the same amount)
- Start the number axis at **0**

sections.title: What We Learned
sections.content:
Awesome work! In this lesson you learned:

- **Bar graphs** use bars to compare categories
- **Dot plots** use dots above a number line to show data spread
- Both need a **title**, **labels** and a **scale**
- The **mode** is the most common value (the tallest bar or stack)

Try collecting data from your class and creating your own bar graph!

workedExamples.title: Interpreting a Bar Graph
workedExamples.problem: A bar graph shows book genres: Adventure = 14, Mystery = 9, Fantasy = 11, Comedy = 6. What is the total number of books?
steps: Read each bar: Adventure (14), Mystery (9), Fantasy (11), Comedy (6)
workedExamples.explanation: To find the total, add the values of all the bars: $14 + 9 + 11 + 6 = 40$.

workedExamples.title: Reading a Dot Plot
workedExamples.problem: A dot plot shows the number of siblings students have. The stacks are: 0 siblings (4 dots), 1 sibling (8 dots), 2 siblings (6 dots), 3 siblings (2 dots). What is the mode?
steps: The mode is the value with the most dots
The tallest stack is at 1 sibling (8 dots)
workedExamples.explanation: The mode is the most common value. Since 8 students have 1 sibling (more than any other number), the mode is 1.

title: Describing Chance: From Impossible to Certain
description: Use probability language and simple fractions to describe the chance of events
objectives: Place events on a chance scale from impossible to certain
List all possible outcomes for simple chance experiments
Use simple fractions to describe probability

sections.title: How Likely Is It?
sections.content: In Level 2, you learned words like likely, unlikely, certain and impossible. Now let's go deeper! We'll learn to list all possible **outcomes** and even use **fractions** to describe how likely something is.

sections.title: The Chance Scale
sections.content:
We can place events on a **chance scale** from impossible to certain:

$$\text{Impossible} \longleftrightarrow \text{Unlikely} \longleftrightarrow \text{Even chance} \longleftrightarrow \text{Likely} \longleftrightarrow \text{Certain}$$

| Word | Meaning | Fraction |
|------|---------|----------|
| **Impossible** | Cannot happen | $0$ |
| **Unlikely** | Probably won't happen | Less than $\frac{1}{2}$ |
| **Even chance** | Just as likely as not | $\frac{1}{2}$ |
| **Likely** | Probably will happen | More than $\frac{1}{2}$ |
| **Certain** | Will definitely happen | $1$ |

**Outcomes** are all the possible things that could happen.

When you flip a coin, the outcomes are: {Heads, Tails} -- that's **2 outcomes**.

When you roll a dice, the outcomes are: {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6} -- that's **6 outcomes**.

sections.title: Using Fractions for Chance
sections.content:
We can describe the **probability** (chance) of an event using a fraction:

$$\text{Probability} = \frac{\text{number of favourable outcomes}}{\text{total number of outcomes}}$$

**Example: Rolling a dice**
- Probability of rolling a 3: $\frac{1}{6}$ (1 favourable outcome out of 6)
- Probability of rolling an even number (2, 4 or 6): $\frac{3}{6} = \frac{1}{2}$
- Probability of rolling a number less than 7: $\frac{6}{6} = 1$ (certain!)
- Probability of rolling a 7: $\frac{0}{6} = 0$ (impossible!)

**Example: Drawing from a bag**
A bag has 3 red, 2 blue and 5 green marbles (10 total).
- Probability of red: $\frac{3}{10}$
- Probability of blue: $\frac{2}{10}$
- Probability of green: $\frac{5}{10} = \frac{1}{2}$

sections.title: Example: Listing Outcomes
sections.content: A spinner has 4 equal sections coloured red, blue, green and yellow. What are the possible outcomes? What is the probability of spinning blue?
steps: List all outcomes: {Red, Blue, Green, Yellow}
Favourable outcomes for blue: 1 (only one blue section)

sections.title: Fair and Unfair
sections.content:
An experiment is **fair** when all outcomes have an **equal chance** of happening.

**Fair examples:**
- A normal coin: heads and tails are equally likely ($\frac{1}{2}$ each)
- A normal dice: each number is equally likely ($\frac{1}{6}$ each)
- A spinner with equal sections

**Unfair examples:**
- A spinner with one section much bigger than the others
- A weighted dice
- Drawing from a bag where there are more of one colour

In a fair experiment, if there are $n$ outcomes, each has a probability of $\frac{1}{n}$.

sections.title: What We Learned
sections.content:
Superb! In this lesson you learned:

- Events range from **impossible** ($0$) to **certain** ($1$)
- **Outcomes** are all the things that could happen
- Probability = $\frac{\text{favourable outcomes}}{\text{total outcomes}}$
- **Even chance** = $\frac{1}{2}$
- An experiment is **fair** when all outcomes are equally likely

Try flipping a coin 20 times -- do you get heads about half the time?

workedExamples.title: Listing Outcomes and Finding Probability
workedExamples.problem: A bag has 4 red balls and 6 blue balls. What is the probability of picking a red ball?
workedExamples.solution: The probability of picking red is $\frac{4}{10}$ (or $\frac{2}{5}$).
workedExamples.explanation: There are 4 red balls out of 10 total balls. The probability is $\frac{4}{10}$, which simplifies to $\frac{2}{5}$.

workedExamples.title: Dice Probability
workedExamples.problem: What is the probability of rolling a number greater than 4 on a standard dice?
workedExamples.explanation: Only 2 out of the 6 possible outcomes (5 and 6) are greater than 4. So the probability is $\frac{2}{6} = \frac{1}{3}$.
